quizInfo.Subject: Information Management
quizInfo.Title: Database Models
References: Any external links/handouts should be referenced here

quizData.question: Focuses on how the database structure will be used to store and manage end-user data.
This refers on the process of creating a specific data model for a determined problem domain.
This refers to the first step in designing a database.
This refers to a relatively simple representation that is usually graphical.
This refers to a representation of more complex real-world data structures.
This refers to an abstraction of a more complex real-world object or event.
Data models can facilitate interaction among the designer, the applications programmer, and the end user.
A well-developed data model can even foster improved understanding of the organization for which the database design is developed.
The importance of data modeling cannot be understated.
__________ constitutes the most basic information used by a system.
__________ are created to manage data and to help transform data into information.
Data is viewed the same ways by different people.
The following are the basic building blocks for data model EXCEPT ONE.
This data model basic building block refers to a person, place, thing, or event about which data will be collected and stored.
This data model basic building block refers to a characteristic of an entity.
This data model basic building block refers to an association among entitites.
These are the three types of relationships EXCEPT ONE.
This data model was developed in the 1960s to manage large amounts of data for complex manufacturing projects.
This data model was created to represent complex data relationships more effectively than the hierarchical model in order to improve database performance, and to impose a database standard.
This data model was introduced in 1970 by E.F. Codd of IBM.
This data model was introduced in 1976 by Peter Chen.
This data model's basic logical structure is represented by an upside-down tree that contains levels, or segments.
This data model's segment is the equivalent of a file system's record type.
This data model is generally used today.
This data model represented a major breakthrough for both users and designers.
This data model uses a foundatinal mathematical concept known as a relation.
This data model's graphical representation of entitites and their relationships in a database structure complemented the relational data model concepts.
This standard database concept of a network model refer to the conceptual organization of the entire database as viewed by the database administrator.
This standard database concept of a network model defines the portion of the database by the application programs that actually produce the desired information from the data in the database.
This standard database concept of a network model defines the environment in which data can be managed.
This standard database concept of a network model allows the database administrator to define the schema components.
Increasingly complex real-world problems demonstrated a need for a data model that more closely represented the real world.
In this data model, both data and its relationships are contained in a single structure known as an object.
What does OODBMS mean? It is which the Object-Oriented Data Model is the basis of.
This component of OODBM says that an object is an abstraction of a real-world entity.
This component of OODBM says that an attribute is the properties of a class.
This component of OODBM says that objects share similar characteristics are grouped in classes.
This component of OODBM says that a class is a collection of similar objects with shared structure and behavior.
This component of OODBM says that class are organized in an object hierarchy.
This component of OODBM says that a class hierarchy resembles a downright up tree in which each class has only one parent.
This component of OODBM says that inheritance is the ability of an object within the class hierarchy to inherit attribute.
This component of OODBM says that Object-Oriented Data Models are typically depicted using Unified Modeling Language (UML) class diagrams.
This is a metalanguage used to represent and manipulate data elements and permits the manipulation of a document's data elements.
Unlike other markup languages, XML permits the manipulation of a document's data elements.
It refers to a movement to find new and better ways to manage large amounts of web and sensor-generated data.
The term 'Big Data' have been first used in a computing framework by ____________ who is a Silicon Graphics scientist in the 1990s.
____________ first described the basic characteristics of Big Data databases.
The following are the characteristics of Big Data databases EXCEPT ONE.
This characteristic of a Big Data Database refers to the amount of data being stored.
This characteristic of a Big Data Database refers to the speed with which data grows and the need to process this data quickly in order to generate information and insight.
This characteristic refers to the fact that the data being collected comes in multiple data formats.
This is a large-scale distributed database system that stores structured and unstructured data in efficient ways.
This characteristic of a NoSQL database entails that they are not based on the relational model and SQL, hence the name NoSQL.
This characteristic of a NoSQL database entails that it doesn't support distributed database architectures.
This characteristic of a NoSQL database entails that it provides high scalability, availability, and fault tolerance.
This characteristic of a NoSQL database entails that it doesn't support large amounts of sparse data.
This characteristic of a NoSQL database entails that it is geared toward performance rather than transaction consistency.
One of the big advantages of NoSQL databases is that they generally use a _____________ database node.
NoSQL databases can handle very high volumes of data and is suited for ___________ data.
NoSQL databases are designed to support ________ operations.
One of the biggest problems of very large distributed databases are enforcing _______________.
Distributed databases automatically make copies of data elements at ____________________ to ensure high availability and fault tolerance.
This institute defined a framework for data modeling based on degrees of data abstraction in the early 1970s.
quizData.answer: American National Standards Institute Standards Planning and Requirements Committee
choices: American National Standards Institute Standards Planning and Requirements Committee
American Institute for Standards Planning and Requirements Committee
American National Institute for Standards Planning and Committee of Requirements
American Committee for National Standards and Planning Institute

quizData.question: These are the three levels of data abstraction as defined by the resulting ANSI/SPARC architecture EXCEPT ONE.
This level of data abstraction is the end user's view of the data environment.
This level of data abstraction refers to people who use the application programs to manipulate the data and generate information.
This schema of a level of data abstraction is a specific representation of its external model, using the database constructs supported by the chosen database.
This level of data abstraction represents a global view of the entire database by the entire organization.
This schema of level of data abstraction is the basis for the identification and high-level description of the main data objects.
This level of data abstraction is the representation of the database a seen by the DBMS.
This level of data abstraction requires the designer to match the conceptual model's characteristics and constraints to those of the selected implementation model.
This schema of a level of data abstraction is a specific representation of its model, using the database constructs supported by the chosen database.
This level of data abstraction operates at the lowest level, describing the way data is saved on storage media such as magnetic, solid state, or optical media.

This level of data abstraction requires the definition of both real-world storage devices and access ethods required to reach the data within those storage devices, making it both software and hardware dependent.
